text: I really enjoyed the first Milewski video! I too don't want to get bogged down in philosophy but it's fun so I'll put some comments to <@UJK8MKYAZ>'s point in a thread to this post

elements.text: I really enjoyed the first Milewski video! I too don't want to get bogged down in philosophy but it's fun so I'll put some comments to
's point in a thread to this post

text:
I also watched some other videos related yesterday (Wadler's Propositions as Types <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IOiZatlZtGU> from <@UJFN50C00> and the Erik Meijer video from <@UHWC9PXBL> <https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JMP6gI5mLHc)> and they both were pushing the opposite idea: the fact that category theory has exposed these deep relationships between diverse fields *is itself evidence* of *discovery of facts about the universe*. So I think he was responding to that point of view, and trying to explain the mystery of "why do all these things connect?" with a different philosophical bent.

And I happen to have a very similar point of view to him. I too think all these things connect because they are all formalisms made by humans -- as opposed to thinking they have existed in a platonic ideal and we somehow plucked them out. (I know that was a bit of a strawman, so help me out with the alternative perspective: what does it mean to discover something?) I am definitely an amateur philosopher, so feel free to school me, but my thought is that all we can ever do is touch reality indirectly (we can never have true knowledge of the world because where would it come from?), so we can never discover anything, we can only invent hypothesis or maps about what is there, and over time improve our maps bit by bit, but never perfecting them.

Mathematics is a very strange system of "maps" because it keeps new creating maps to talk about existing maps. And category theory is a very high-level map that can fit a a lot of other maps on it.

I don't think it's a self-contradiction to say that category theory is the most powerful tool humans have invented to think about compositionality... and compositionality is the most powerful tools humans have to think about complex problems. Thus, why we study category theory. Maps are designed to correspond to the world (including other maps, which exist in the world) -- but they aren't the world. They were *invented* by humans doing their best to model the world.

text: My thoughts on this have been strongly influenced by David Deutch (in the Popper school of thought) and Seymour Papert's constructionism (in the Piaget school of thought)

text: I have a very rough and rambly draft of more thoughts in this vein if you want more... <https://futureofcoding.org/drafts/invented-or-discovered>

text: Isn’t it obvious, though? The arrows represent our primal hunting instinct, complete with barbs and such. The objects are mammoths… :face_with_rolling_eyes:

text: When someone is snarky about the things that make us human, I have no qualms being snarky right back. At the risk of sounding utilitarian, I assert that if we tear down the belief in true knowledge of anything outside our selves, we’ll torn down human society and happiness with it.

elements.text: When someone is snarky about the things that make us human, I have no qualms being snarky right back. At the risk of sounding utilitarian, I assert that if we tear down the belief in true knowledge of anything outside our selves, we’ll torn down human society and happiness with it.

text:
Reading the philosophical discussion it occurred to me that thanks to the abstract / general nature of category theory, there are as many different reasons why people are interested in it. I'm interested in it for actually quite practical reasons. Thought I'll list a few here, to provide a counter-balance to the more philosophically themed discussion (which is also valid, just not my cup of tea):

• There's the connection between *type systems* and categories. As I mentioned in the call, category theory felt like finding the missing pages of the Haskell manual to me. Suddenly a lot more of the type stuff in Haskell made so much more sense to me, e.g. types as set of (possible) values, abstract data types and their composition, higher-kinded types, etc. For me a lot of things I thought I understand suddenly "clicked"; I had a lot of valuable "Aha!" moments that I'm sure make me a better functional programmer.
• As <@UA14TGLTC> pointed out during the call, there's a super-tight connection between (relational) *databases* and categories. The _Seven Sketches_ book introduces categories using this connection in chapter 3. They allude to (and there is further research from one of the authors) that category theory provides a formal way of transforming one relational database schema into another, which I find very useful for building more flexible universal data models, which is one of the things I'm exploring currently.
• *Graphs* can also trivially be converted into (free) categories, which means there is a visual representation that comes with denotational semantics out-of-the-box. Which somehow seems interesting to me, if you're also into visual programming languages… that's also what the _Graphical Linear Algebra_ blog is rooted in.

Overall there appears to be a lot of power in Functors — the "magic" behind your friendly `map()` function in your favorite programming language, except that that's just one incarnation of the concept, and it seems to work in lots of other contexts too. I want to understand this well enough to be able to apply this to other domains.

Take all this with a grain of salt, as I'm still learning and might not really understand what I'm talking about…

text: Oh, and I hear it helps you understand monads too. :wink:

text:
From the first meeting i took away, among other things, this idea:

Category Theory inverts the common perspective of inspecting things to inspecting relationships between things.

Is that a fair representation? Is it a complete representation? The first time I felt i understood the mental model that category theory was suggesting was watching eric's talks <https://purelyfunctional.tv/courses/category-theory/>

I think he did a good job of building from a concert example i could relate to the abstractions that category theory presents and it was done by talking about the relationships between relationships in a recursive manor.

attachments.title: Category Theory from the Universe Up - Video Course - PurelyFunctional.tv
attachments.text: Ever been completely baffled by Wikipedia articles on Monads and Functors? Are you curious about what everybody is raving about, but can't find any good ways to learn it? It turns out that many of the ideas of category theory come almost directly from the real world. Wouldn't you like to understand how those concepts relate to the real world?
attachments.fallback: PurelyFunctional.tv: Category Theory from the Universe Up - Video Course - PurelyFunctional.tv

text:
<@UJNJQD2AC> Yes, I’d say that’s a fair representation. The trick seems to be to define (and prove) everything just with relationships, so that you don’t assume anything about the objects. Which makes it so generic. Because you make no assumptions about them at all, objects can be anything.
That's where it's a step up over set theory, where a lot of the constructs and proofs are based on assumptions on the objects themselves, in addition to relations between them.

The trick++ later on then is to go all recursive or self-referential and stick the concepts of category theory itself (categories, functors, etc.) into those proven relationship-only constructs as categories and end up with even higher-level constructs which turn out to simplify some of the lower level proofs. At least that’s how I understand it currently.
It's all fascinatingly weird and driven by obsessive over-optimization driving a concept to its extreme. :-)

! That makes sense to me.

text: hmm... I think I agree with the premise (we're all trapped inside some kind of language-ish thing and relate to it rather than the world directly) but I think that also means we can't even relate to language directly—we have language about language and are always one step distanced from it. so we invent a new concept ("red", or "morphisms") but certainly don't know all the possible uses of those concepts. so we kind of smash them together and find out new things about our inventions, which feels like discovery. but to your point the discovery is about the capabilities of our invented constructs rather than the universe directly

text: there's almost a macro-style quoting issue here: we discover facts about "the world" rather than the actual world, but doesn't the argument bottom out here? we never interact with the actual world, just our linguistic perception of it

text: I'm with you. The distinction I'd make is that "finding new things out about our inventions" is itself invention.
